Komentar Mateja Lahovnika: Boleč trenutek resnice
Ukrep Banke Slovenije razkriva precej nizko kupno moč plač in pokojnin.
03 Nov 2019, 21:25 by Matej Lahovnik
Malokateri ukrep Banke Slovenije je tako razburil javnost kot zaostritev pogojev za kreditiranje potrošnikov. Bolj kot zaostritev kreditiranja bi ljudi verjetno razburila le uvedba ležarin za depozite. V Združenju bank Slovenije so takoj izračunali, da bo omejitev kreditiranja prizadela več kot 300.000 ljudi.
Ukrep Banke Slovenije razkriva precej nizko kupno moč plač in pokojnin.
Banka Slovenije je potegnila ročno zavoro, ker se očitno bojijo, da z obstoječimi plačami in pokojninami ne bomo zmogli odplačevati vseh najetih kreditov. Po novem mora potrošniku po plačilu vseh obrokov posojila vsak mesec ostati najmanj znesek v višini 76 odstotkov minimalne bruto plače, kar trenutno znaša 674 evrov, od novega leta pa bo to 715 evrov. Posojilna sposobnost se zmanjša še za potrebna denarna sredstva za preživljanje vzdrževanih družinskih članov.Narobe bi bilo kriviti sedanjega guvernerja Banke Slovenije, ker opozarja na potrebno previdnost pri kreditiranju potrošnikov in predlaga temu primerne ukrepe. Banka Slovenije ni odgovorna za nizke pokojnine in plače v Sloveniji, temveč za stabilnost bančnega sistema. Pravzaprav smo doživeli boleč trenutek resnice, ker ukrep Banke Slovenije razkriva precej nizko kupno moč plač in pokojnin.Dve tretjini zaposlenih ima neto plačo pod 1100 evri, povprečna pokojnina pa znaša okrog 657 evrov. To pomeni, da večina upokojencev in veliko zaposlenih s plačo pod povprečjem ne bo več kreditno sposobnih. Strožji pogoji kreditiranja potrošnikov se bodo zato precej poznali na kupni moči in posledično na manjši prodaji trgovskega blaga. Omejitev sicer velja le za banke in hranilnice, ne pa tudi za podjetja, ki se ukvarjajo z lizingom.Obstaja tudi nevarnost, da se bodo potrošniki dražje zadolževali na sivem trgu. Banka Slovenije je tako rekoč polila s hladno prho tako banke kot potrošnike pred prihajajočim veselim decembrom, zato bo prodaja zanesljivo nižja, kot bi bila brez tega ukrepa.Škoda le, da Banka Slovenije ni imela enakih vatlov tudi pred zadnjo gospodarsko krizo, ko so menedžerji pri bankah kratkoročno zadolžili podjetja z namenom menedžerskih prevzemov in nekatera skoraj potopili.

Matthew Lahovnik's Commentary: A painful moment of truth
The Bank of Slovenia's measure reveals a rather low purchasing power of salaries and pensions.
03 Nov 2019, 21:25 by Matej Lahovnik
Few actions by the Bank of Slovenia have both angered the public and tightened consumer credit conditions. More than tightening lending, people would probably be upset by the introduction of deposit deposits. The Banking Association of Slovenia immediately calculated that more than 300,000 people would be affected by the credit limit.
The Bank of Slovenia's measure reveals a rather low purchasing power of salaries and pensions.
The Bank of Slovenia has pulled the parking brake because they are clearly afraid that with existing salaries and pensions we will not be able to repay all the loans we have borrowed. Accordingly, after paying all the loan installments, the consumer must remain in possession of at least 76% of the minimum gross wage each month, which is currently EUR 674, which will be EUR 715 from the new year. The lending capacity is further reduced by the necessary cash to support dependents. It would be blameworthy to blame the current Governor of the Bank of Slovenia for pointing out the necessary caution in lending to consumers and proposing appropriate measures. The Bank of Slovenia is not responsible for low pensions and salaries in Slovenia, but for the stability of the banking system. In fact, we experienced a painful moment of truth because the Bank of Slovenia's measure reveals a rather low purchasing power of salaries and pensions. Two-thirds of employees have a net salary of less than € 1,100, with an average pension of about € 657. This means that most retirees and many low-wage employees will no longer be creditworthy. Stricter consumer lending conditions will therefore be much more evident in purchasing power and, consequently, in lower sales of merchandise. The restriction applies only to banks and savings banks, but not to leasing companies. There is also a risk that consumers will be more expensive to borrow in the gray market. The Bank of Slovenia practically poured a cold shower on both banks and consumers before the coming happy December, so the sales will be reliably lower than they would have been without this measure. borrowed from the banks for the short-term with the intention of managerial acquisitions and almost sunk some.
